title: Blue Pottery
hero_image_alt: Iconic blue and white floral pottery from Jaipur
short_description: A unique pottery style from Jaipur that uses quartz powder instead of clay, famous for its vibrant blue and floral patterns.
long_description:
Blue Pottery is widely recognized as a traditional craft of Jaipur, though it is Turko-Persian in origin. The name comes from the eye-catching cobalt blue dye used to color the pottery. It is one of the few pottery techniques in the world that does not use clay. Instead, the dough for the pottery is prepared by mixing quartz stone powder, powdered glass, Multani Mitti (Fuller's Earth), borax, gum, and water.

The technique was brought to India by early Muslim rulers and later patronized by the Maharajas of Jaipur. It is a fragile but beautiful art form, primarily used for decorative items like vases, bowls, plates, and tiles. The distinctive blue color (derived from cobalt oxide) and green (from copper oxide) against a white background give it its cool, refreshing look.
traditional_methods: Dough Preparation: Mixing quartz, glass, and binders.
Molding: Pressing the dough into molds (no potter's wheel used).
Finishing: Smoothing and applying a white 'engobe' base.
Painting: Freehand painting with oxide pigments.
Glazing: Applying a lead-free glass glaze.

major_centres.title: Sanganer, Jaipur
major_centres.summary: A hub for craft workshops including blue pottery and block printing.
major_centres.how_to_reach: Short drive from Jaipur city center.

shipping_and_packaging_tips: Extremely fragile. Ensure bubble wrap and double boxing. Carry-on luggage recommended for small items.
authenticity_tips: Genuine Blue Pottery is lighter than clay pottery and will develop cracks if handled roughly but shouldn't have visible cracks when new. It is opaque.
sustainability_notes: Uses waste glass and quartz, saving river clay. Lead-free glazes are now common.
local_economy_note: Supports hundreds of artisan families in and around Jaipur.

notable_artisans.name: Kripal Singh Shekhawat
notable_artisans.note: Revived the art form in the 1960s.
